awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Electronic Coherence Effects in Multichromophore Systems Probed by Two-Dimensional Electronic Spectroscopy
awd_abstract_narration:
In this collaborative project, co-funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics & Mechanisms B and the Chemical Structure, Dynamics & Mechanisms A programs of the Chemistry Division, Professor Lin X. Chen of the Department of Chemistry at Northwestern University and Professor Felix N. Castellano from the Department of Chemistry at North Carolina State University lead a project to understand the effects of coherent electronic motions in energy and electron transfer in distinct classes of multi-chromophoric synthetic platforms.  The knowledge obtained through the proposed studies will greatly enhance the ability to rationally design chemical materials/devices for catalysis, optoelectronics, and energy sustainability.  The proposed research engages University graduate students to use advanced laser spectroscopy for characterization, incorporates state-of-the-art computational chemistry for quantum mechanical and molecular dynamics modeling, and utilizes advanced chemistry laboratory facilities for molecular syntheses and structural characterization, engendering them with expansive training necessary for the development of multidisciplinary scientific expertise.   The proposed research/education activities are integrated with numerous K-12 public outreach activities at both universities, including Photonics Day at North Carolina State University and NU Bond at Northwestern University.   

Specifically, they will employ newly developed two-dimensional electronic spectroscopy in their studies with very high time resolution of approximately 6 femtoseconds. The rationally designed molecules are engineered to tune electronic coupling in their excited states, which are either responsible for or can be correlated to electronic coherence originating from in-phase motions of electrons induced by photoexcitation. The measured coherences will be correlated with the observation of photoinduced intramolecular energy and/or electron transfer chemistry and rationalized using continuously developing theory to assess the role of electronic and/or vibronic coherence in these fundamental primary processes related to light activation. Two types of molecular designs are targeted for these investigations: (1) Pt(II) dimers bridged by hydroxypyridines featuring metal-metal-to-ligand charge transfer excited states where a metal-metal bond is transiently formed following light excitation; and (2) Pt(II) dimers whose terminal cyclometalating ligands are decorated with bay-substituted naphthalenediimide based energy and/or electron acceptors.  The proposed project seeks to glean new insight into excited state chemistry and how this knowledge can be leveraged to control reactivity in condensed phases, molecular photonics, and photocatalysis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The overarching theme of this collaborative project between the Castellano (North Carolina State University) and Chen (Northwestern University) laboratories was to investigate systematic structural control over light-triggered metal-metal bond-forming processes in precisely controlled molecular architectures and their subsequent relaxation processes resulting in the breaking of this same metal-metal bond. This research ultimately seeks an understanding of intrinsic electronic couplings between two metal centers in transition metal-containing molecules and their influence on photochemical reactivity. Specifically, we designed multiple series of transition metal-based dimers where a metal-metal bond is formed following visible light excitation between two Pt(II) metal centers held together in close spatial proximity. These molecules exhibit distance-dependent light absorption, electrochemical, and photophysical behavior, structurally varied applying rational chemical synthesis approaches resulting in the modulation of the metal-metal distances and relative geometries through the structural design of the ligand frameworks. The work at NC State focused on the design, synthesis, and structural characterization of the molecules at the heart of the study while the work at Northwestern applied sophisticated ultrafast spectroscopies revealing the excited state evolution of these molecules as a function of time. The latter used ultrashort excitation laser pulses as short as 7 femtoseconds to accomplish cutting-edge ultrafast optical transient absorption and two-dimensional spectroscopy on these molecules for the first time. The most impactful results from these investigations were recently reported in the scientific journal Nature in 2023, which revealed the interplay between the dynamics of electron spin and the vibrational dynamics of the nuclei in molecules on superfast time scales, which is termed the spin-vibronic effect. Electron spin and vibrational motion cannot be treated independently as they mix and affect electronic dynamics in a complex manner, moving beyond the assumptions of the Born-Oppenheimer approximation wherein the motion of nuclei and electrons in a molecule are independent of each other and can be treated separately. The breakdown of this assumption was a consequence of performing experiments on the 7 femtosecond timescale, revealing the close relationship between the dynamics of nuclei and electrons in the Pt(II) chromophores at the heart of this investigation. This spin-vibronic effect in these molecules altered their energy landscape, increasing the probability and rate of intersystem crossing while revealing intermediate electronic states that were integral to the operation of the spin-vibronic effect. Our discovery could influence the design of molecules useful for solar energy conversion, energy production, quantum information science, and beyond.

Our research engaged graduate students and postdoctoral associates to use advanced laser spectroscopy for characterization, incorporated state-of-the-art computational chemistry for quantum mechanical and molecular dynamics modeling, and utilized advanced chemistry laboratory facilities for molecular synthesis, providing them with an expansive training ground for developing multidisciplinary expertise. Such training is essential for the next generation STEM workforce to explore the frontiers of the chemical sciences and ensure US global competitiveness at the frontiers of scientific knowledge. The diverse and interdisciplinary project has primarily supported a female doctoral graduate researcher over the duration of the award and one undergraduate student supported during the summer months at North Carolina State University. The NC State and Northwestern collaborators have extensively collaborated in the pursuit of this project, resulting in several co-authored peer-reviewed manuscripts and presentations at numerous professional scientific meetings throughout the duration of the award period.

 


Last Modified: 11/08/2023
Modified by: Felix N Castellano
